free_text.Learning outcomes: [li] To provide a comprehensive overview of present days techniques and methods to realize micro- and nano-structures in glass.[br/][li] To provide an in-depth understanding of microscopic mechanisms which are at the basis of glass micromachining.[br/][li] To discuss complete microfabrication processes for the realization of glass micro- and nano-structures.[br/][li] To present examples of modern industrial applications based on glass microstructuring methods.
free_text.Content: 1. Glass as a material[br/]Definition, structure, composition, properties and kinds of glasses[br/][br/]2. Techniques for the microstructuring of glass[br/]Wet etching, dry etching, ultrasonic drilling,  powder blasting, laser structuring and photosensitive glass[br/][br/]3. Replication of glass microstructures[br/]The sol-gel process (spin-on-glass), photosensitive spin-on-glass, the replication process (moulding, de-moulding, annealing)[br/][br/]4. Bonding of glass[br/]Anodic bonding, fusion bonding, pressure-assisted bonding, chemical bonding[br/][br/]5. Applications of glass microstructures[br/]a. Optical systems  (Wave guides, gratings, lenses)[br/]b. Bio-chemical systems (Bio-separation and microfluidics, biosensors)[br/]c. Mechanical systems (Pressure sensors, inkjet printing heads)
free_text.Keywords: Glass, microstructuring, replication, sol-gel process, bonding
free_text.Required prior knowledge: [li] Introductory course to materials science or microfabrication technologies[br/][li] Basics of chemistry and physics
